column3: Will there be easy pedestrian access to West Station?
Will we have a network of safe, easy, clean bike ways that are usable by young and old, and everyone in between?
Will we have frequent, clean, fully accessible public transit that receives priority above personal motor cars and proves to be the best, most efficient, and simplest way to get around Boston?
Will West Station be accessible by walking?
Why not a ferry service on the Charles River?
How can we make the T more convenient for parents with strollers/young children?
Can we have more bus specific lanes throughout Boston?
Will there ever be a way to get to/from East Boston by foot or by bike?
When will there be a safe way to bike around the Common and Public Garden?
Why is there no safe, convenient, or even possible way of biking to the airport?

How come no new stations have been added to the MBTA since 1987 (with the exception of Assembly where there was already track, and which was basically subsidized by the developer)? Even the Green Line Extension (which is far from a done deal) is only happening because it was forced by the Feds as Big Dig mitigation, and, even then, is over a decade behind schedule. Should we even believe that anything will be different in 15 years?
Will there ever be an "outer loop" of sorts that connects the last stop of SOME of the subway lines, so you don't have to go downtown just to go outbound again.

Will Boston ever have a public transit ferry that uses the Charles river (when it isn't frozen) like the CityCat in Brisbane Australia or many other cities with a central river. Even if it was private like the Water Taxi's in Chicago which have rates comparable to public transit. It would improve traffic flow greatly, especially if connected to public transit.
Will there be any more extensions on the Green Line?
Why isn't there more information about routes/where buses and trains are going and coming from and other information?
Can we make better use of Boston's waterways?
How will the system accommodate the aging Baby Boomers?
Will we spend billions of dollars on the Olympics instead of making much needed improvements to our crumbling transportation infrastructure?

Why did we spend $22 billion on the Big Dig for car drivers and leave the MBTA saddled with billions in debt from it? Why can't we have a $22 billion Big Dig for mass transit and force car drivers to pay for it?
Why do we clear the streets after a snow event but not the sidewalks? Shouldn't taxpayer money go to the most common mode of transportation -- our feet?
What if we had heated outdoor stations (like in Chicago) so that people could stay warm in the winter?
Why is there never enough room on the T?
Can COB institute underground/buried electrical system to protect power outages?

How can we expect real change when the Mayor demotes the transportation department to the level of public works and puts the former parking clerk in charge? Fixing potholes and parking meters, is important, but where is the vision for transportation going to come from?
How can we make smarter and more innovative use of our existing parking spaces?
Will there ever be increased enforcement against cars failing to signal, or blocking the box?
Why is street parking free/subsidized? Why doesn't a resident parking permit cost $1000 per year?
When will we fully invest in public transportation?
When are they gonna make flying cars/or buses?
How will smart cars impact traffic flows?
Will we be able to make commercial deliveries by drone?
What if there were seamless bike rentals?
What if we could load passes onto our Charlie Cards online and have them start working immediately?
Can we invent transport that can fit in your pocket so we never have to park again?
Is it possible to make flying cars?
Reevaluate the Green Line T.
Will there be more bikes on the road than cars?
Does Faneuil Hall have swag?  Cause if it does, it wouldn't go underwater.
Will there be fewer disfunctional trains and buses?
Will we be able to take public transportation 24 hours a day?
Why can't the green line run on time?
Is it possible to set up a subway system that runs every weekday and has express trains that make fewer stops during rush hour while local trains make more stops?
What if the T never broke down?
How will public transport be faster?  The T and buses are just too slow.  Will we have trams?
Isn't it possible to figure out which bus lines are consistently at or over capacity during rush hour and add additional buses?
Why does the Orange Line run 10 minute headways during rush hour?

Will the MBTA ever figure out how to run buses/subways so that people in the middle of the route don't have to stand outside for an hour as bus after bus or train after train go by completely full without stopping.
How do you plan on modernizing the T, especially the Green B Line, so that the service becomes consistent all year and doesn't collapse during the winter?
Can the Red Line run more often?
Will there be more buses and will they run more frequently?
Will the MBTA still be completely non-operational due to snow?
How will we deal with increased flooding and snow storms?
What's the evacuation plan for emergency travel especially on roads that can't handle the outflow like the I-90, Route 9, Route 1,  and I-93?

How can we reclaim our streets from cars? How can we shift from unsafe door zone bike accommodations to world-class separated facilities? How can we use mobile technology to improve wayfinding and encourage walking for short trips?
Will huge advocacy efforts by LivableStreets, BCU, WalkBoston other groups, and individual citizens still be needed for the City to build cycletracks and safe streets?

How come if a driver seriously injures or kills a pedestrian or biker who had the right of way, they rarely if ever face any consequences unless they did it on purpose or were drunk? Why can't we prosecute careless/inattentive drivers who kill?
Will the school buses be safe in the future?
RT @GoBoston2030: What if our transportation cleaned the air? Solid question! What's yours? Donate it to http://t.co/AG3E57jH6z! http://t.câ€¦
Is there a more efficient and environmentally conscious way of removing snow?

Why can't we ban large trucks (18-wheelers, etc) from the city center, as they do in compact European cities? There is no way that the CVS on Boylston St (for instance) is actually getting stocked up with an 18-wheeler full of stuff every day, and these trucks don't fit in our city, cause accidents and traffic jams, and always double park blocking travel lanes and bike lanes. 95% of goods could be switched to smaller vans or box trucks outside of city limits and delivered with no issues.
question
